facts.text: The appellant was the proprietor of the Wanaparthy Jagir in the former Indian State of Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was the proprietor of the Wanaparthy Jagir in the former Indian State of Hyderabad. Certain payments described as interim maintenance allowances were made to him under the Hyderabad

facts.text: Certain payments described as interim maintenance allowances were made to the appellant under the Hyderabad Abolition of Jagirs Regulation 1358 F.

anchor.surface_text: Certain payments described as interim maintenance allowances were made to him under the Hyderabad  Abolition of Jagirs  Regulation 1358 F, hereafter called the Abolition Regulation. These payments were brought to tax under the Income-tax Act, 1922 as income.

facts.text: These payments were brought to tax under the Income-tax Act, 1922 as income.

anchor.surface_text: These payments were brought to tax under the Income-tax Act, 1922 as income. The appellant companytended that they were capital and number liable to be taxed.

facts.text: The appellant contended that the payments were capital and not liable to be taxed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytended that they were capital and number liable to be taxed. He took various proceedings and eventually a case was stated to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh for decision of the following question

facts.text: A case was stated to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh for decision of the question: Whether the interim maintenance allowances received by the assessee under the Hyderabad Abolition of Jagirs Regulation, 1358 Fasli, are income and therefore liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: He took various proceedings and eventually a case was stated to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh for decision of the following question Whether the interim maintenance allowances received by the assessee under the Hyderabad  Abolition of Jagirs  Regulation, 1358 Fasli, are income and therefore liable to tax.

facts.text: The question was answered against the appellant by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The question was answered against the appellant by the High Court and hence this appeal. The point at issue is whether these payments companystituted capital or income.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 3, 1959 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petition No. 17 of 1956 Referred Case.

facts.text: Under s. 6 of the Abolition Regulation, the jagirs were included in Diwani Government as from the appointed day.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 6 of this Regulation, the jagirs were included in Diwani  Government  as from the appointed day to be fixed under s. 5 and thereupon the powers, rights and liabilities of the Jagirdars in relation to the Jagirs ceased to be exercisable by or against them.

facts.text: Section 14 of the Abolition Regulation provided that the amounts payable to jagirdars under Regulation shall be deemed to be interim maintenance allowances payable until such time as the terms for the commutation of Jagirs are determined.

anchor.surface_text: Section 14 provided that the amounts payable to jagirdars under Regulation shall be deemed to be interim maintenance allowances payable until such time as the terms for the companymutation of Jagirs are determined. facts.text: The commutation sum for a Jagir would be a certain multiple of its basic annual revenue under Section 3 of the Commutation Regulation.
